content:
Sharing behind-the-scenes content on Instagram stories is a fantastic idea! Instagram is a visually-driven platform, and behind-the-scenes content can help give your audience a sense of exclusivity and intimacy with your brand.

Sharing sneak peeks of new products or features can create buzz and anticipation, and Instagram stories are a great way to do that. Since Instagram stories disappear after 24 hours, it's a low-risk way to test the waters and see how your audience responds to new content.

By sharing behind-the-scenes content on Instagram, you can:

1. Drive engagement: Instagram stories allow you to ask questions, poll your audience, and encourage them to share their thoughts and feedback.
2. Build anticipation: Share sneak peeks of new products or features to create excitement and anticipation among your audience.
3. Humanize your brand: Instagram stories can help showcase the people behind the brand, making your audience feel more connected to your business.
4. Drive traffic: You can use Instagram stories to drive traffic to your Twitter account, website, or other social media platforms.

Since you're already planning to share behind-the-scenes content on Twitter, you can use Instagram stories to supplement that content and provide a different perspective. You can share more visual, behind-the-scenes content on Instagram, and use Twitter to share more in-depth, text-based content.

Here's a possible approach:

* Share behind-the-scenes content on Twitter, focusing on the "day in the life" type of content we discussed earlier.
* Use Instagram stories to share more visual, sneak-peek type content, such as:
	+ Sneak peeks of new products or features
	+ Behind-the-scenes shots of your design process
	+ Quick tutorials or tips related to your products
	+ Q&A sessions or polls to engage with your audience

By using both Twitter and Instagram, you can create a cohesive brand story across multiple platforms and engage with your audience in different ways.

What do you think? Are you ready to give Instagram stories a try?
